example 1:
Title : Displays
Feature Description : The cockpit and the passengers will be surrounded by a set of displays (touch and non-touch).
These Displays will fulfil conventional functions (i.e. Driver Information, Infotainment, HVAC controls, Vehicle and User settings) as well as new E-Mirror technologies (i.e. cameras fed videos rendered on 3 displays surrounding the driver)The DRVM will replace interior windshield mirrors and will render on the screen sharingalso Driver Information.The CMS will replace exterior door mirrorsand will render its videos on side displays adjacent to the Cluster.
In various equipment levels the passengersmight benefit for some additional touch displays: front row – embedded, second row – portable after-market.

Benefits and Competitive solutions:Proposed technology: TFT
Pro: Multiple off-the-shelf components available on the market with various suppliers.
Con: Could be perceived as “old technology” by 2025+ sales timeframe

• Alternative technology: OLED
Pro: Brilliant and vivid colours, with crisp graphical assets
Non conventional shapes and curvatures could be achieved
Cons: Expensive technology not yet mainstreamed by the automotive industry

Functional Needs : The cockpit will share 2 physical displays:
12.3” – used in Cluster, Center and Co-Driver packages
7” – used in CMS and Rear Occupant packages
All displays shall be used in landscape layout orientation, excepting the center stack screen which shall be in portrait orientation.

The Driver Information Display shall reserve a portion of its User Interface for the Digital Rear View Mirror. The whole system shall be rated as ASIL-B (TBD) compliant.
The Camera Monitoring System Displays will be placed on the sides near the DID, and will share the same packaging under same curved optically bonded glass. Also the CMS system shall be rated as ASIL-B (TBD) compliant.
The same 3x Displays packages shall integrate in its package behind the glass also the Driver Monitoring System, including Camera and infrared LEDs.

The Center and Co-Driver Displays will reserve on their touch surface area also HVAC and other Infotainment and Vehicle controls.
Detailed Graphical User Interface definition and functions will follow parallel to the HW development activities.
Partially the CSD shall be capable of complying with Functional Safety requirements, allowing ASIL-B rated functions to be used through the defined GUI (TBD).

The Co-Driver should be able to experience a higher level of User Interaction in higher specification vehicles, by adding 2 additional displays adjacent to the CDD, mirroring the displays physical package of the driver (TBD).

As standard the rear occupants shall be provided minimum interface possibilities with the vehicle – e.g. (rear) HVAC controls – through a center mounted touch display.

As optional in higher specification cars, the rear occupant would be able to bring portable aftermarket screened devices (i.e. tablets) and dock them into the backrests of front row seats.Through special connection and developed application they could connect to the IVI system and the rest of the vehicle.

Advice:

1. Consider both TFT and OLED technologies and weigh the pros and cons of each technology. Make a decision based on factors such as cost, availability, and consumer preferences.
2. Ensure that the displays meet the functional needs and safety requirements, such as the ASIL-B rating and landscape/portrait orientation.
3. Consider the user experience and provide a detailed graphical user interface definition for the displays.
4. Consider offering additional touch displays for the passengers, particularly in higher specification vehicles.
5. Explore the possibility of integrating portable devices for the rear occupants in higher specification vehicles.
6. Consider the integration of the different display systems and ensure that they work seamlessly with each other and with the rest of the vehicle.

1. Feature description
2. Benefits and competitive solutions
3. functional needs

1. Feature Description: Smartphone mirroring is a technology that allows a driver to connect their smartphone to their car's infotainment system, allowing the phone's screen to be mirrored onto the car's display. This allows the driver to access and control their smartphone's apps, music, and navigation directly from their car's screen.
2. Benefits and Competitive Solutions:
Proposed Technology: Wireless connectivity technologies such as Bluetooth, Wi-Fi Direct, or Apple CarPlay and Android Auto.
Pro: Easy to use, no need to physically connect the phone to the car, multiple device compatibility, and seamless integration with the car's infotainment system.
Con: Dependent on phone's battery life, potential connectivity and compatibility issues.
3. Functional Needs:
[Display] The mirrored smartphone screen should be displayed clearly and in full resolution on the car's display.
[Control] The driver should be able to control their smartphone's apps, music, and navigation directly from the car's infotainment system.
[Connectivity] The car's infotainment system should be able to establish a stable and secure connection with the smartphone.
[Compatibility] The technology should be compatible with a wide range of popular smartphone brands and operating systems.
[Settings] The driver should be able to adjust the display settings, such as brightness and screen orientation, for optimal use.
[User interface] The user interface of the smartphone mirroring technology should be intuitive and easy to use.

"Benefits and Competitive Solutions" refers to the advantages and alternatives of a particular product or technology. It provides information on what sets the product apart from its competitors and what benefits it offers to its users. This information can help consumers compare products and make informed decisions about what product best suits their needs. It is typically comprised of a list of pros and cons and a comparison of the product with other similar products in the market.

1. Feature description
2. Benefits and competitive solutions
3. functional needs

1. Feature Description: Voice control system allows drivers to control various functions in the vehicle using voice commands. It enables drivers to operate the car's entertainment system, navigation, climate control, and other features without having to physically touch the controls.
2. Benefits and Competitive Solutions:
• Hands-free operation, allowing the driver to keep their hands on the wheel and eyes on the road.
• Reduced distraction while driving, as the driver doesn't have to physically interact with the controls.
• Improved convenience, as the driver can make changes to the car's settings without having to take their focus away from the road.
• Integration with smartphone personal assistants such as Siri or Google Assistant.
• Improved safety, as the driver doesn't have to take their hands off the wheel or look away from the road to make adjustments to the car.
3. Functional Needs:
• [Voice Command] The system should recognize and respond to a wide range of voice commands.
• [Integration] The system should integrate with other systems in the vehicle, such as entertainment, navigation, climate control, and more.
• [Customization] The system should allow for customization of the voice commands and personalization to the user's preferences.
• [Accuracy] The system should accurately recognize and respond to voice commands, even in noisy environments.
• [Connectivity] The system should connect to the driver's smartphone and other devices for seamless integration.
• [Safety] The system should have safety features to prevent incorrect or unintended commands while driving.
• [Feedback] The system should provide visual and auditory feedback to confirm the successful execution of commands.
